name: Checklist I (For Routine Maintenance)
description: A comprehensive checklist for routine ship maintenance covering certificates, equipment, and general safety procedures.

items.text: Is the Flag Registry Certificate valid and on board?
Is the Radio Station License valid and on board?
Is the Class Certificate valid and properly endorsed (AS/IS)?
Is the Load Line Certificate valid and properly endorsed?
Is the Safety Construction Certificate valid and properly endorsed?
items.details: Especially check endorsement at In-Water Survey if carried out independently.

items.text: Is the Safety Equipment Certificate valid and properly endorsed?
Is the Safety Radio Certificate valid and properly endorsed?
Is the International Oil Pollution Prevention Certificate (IOPP) valid and properly endorsed?
Is the International Sewage Pollution Prevention Certificate valid and on board?
Is the International Air Pollution Prevention Certificate (IAPP) valid and on board?
Is the Engine International Air Pollution Prevention (EIAPP) Certificate on board for each applicable diesel engine?
items.details: For each diesel engine with a power output of more than 130kW installed on a ship constructed on or after 1 January 2000.

items.text: Is the International Energy Efficiency Certificate on board?
Is the International Ballast Water Management Certificate (or SOC) on board and valid?
Is the Safety Management Certificate (SMC) valid and properly endorsed for Intermediate Audit?
Is a copy of the Document of Compliance (DOC) on board and endorsed for Annual Audit?
Is the International Ship Security Certificate (ISSC) valid and on board?
Is the Maritime Labour Certificate (MLC) or Statement of Compliance (SOC) valid and properly endorsed for inspections?
Are DMLC Part I and Part II on board and valid?
Is the Minimum Manning Certificate available on board?
Are all officer Certificates of Competence (Master, C/O, C/E, 2/E, Engineer, GMDSS operator) valid and endorsed by the flag state?
items.details: Check regulations II/2, II/1, III/2, III/1, IV/2.

items.text: Do all crew members hold valid Certificates of Proficiency (watch-keeping, basic training, survival craft, advanced fire fighting, etc.)?
Does every crew member have a valid medical certificate?
Are the Stability Information Booklet and Loading Manual approved and understood by the crew?
Is the Shipboard Oil Pollution Emergency Plan (SOPEP) or SMPEP approved and available?
Is the Technical File for NOx emission control verification available?
Is the Emergency Towing Booklet (Procedure) available?
items.details: For all cargo ships 500GT or over.

items.text: Are the Damage Control Plan and Booklet approved and available?
Is the Ship Energy Efficiency Management Plan (SEEMP) available on board?
Is the approved Ballast Water Management Plan (BWMP) on board?
Is the Oil Record Book (Parts I and II) properly recorded?
Is the Garbage Record Book and Garbage Management Plan properly maintained?
Is the Continuous Synopsis Record (CSR) file complete and up-to-date?
Is the Cargo Gear Booklet properly recorded and endorsed?
Are nautical charts for the intended voyage available, up-to-date, and properly corrected?
Are essential nautical publications (Sailing Directions, List of Lights, Notice to Mariners, Tide Tables, etc.) the latest editions and up-to-date?
Are mandatory international conventions (SOLAS, MARPOL, COLREG, ILLC, STCW, MLC) and flag state maritime laws available on board?
Are steering gear tests and drills recorded with date and details in the logbook?
Are abandon ship drills and fire drills recorded with date and details in the logbook?
Are weekly and monthly inspections of survival craft and life-saving appliances recorded in the logbook?
Are Fire Control Plans up-to-date, exhibited in key locations, and stored in watertight containers outside accommodation?
Is the Muster List up-to-date, exhibited in key locations, and written in a language understood by the crew?
Is the Training Manual available and its contents consistent with the ship's current equipment?
Are posters or signs for life-saving appliances provided near their location and using IMO symbols?
Is the pilot ladder in good condition (side ropes, steps) and are proper handholds available?
Is the accommodation ladder/gangway in good order and has it passed its 5-yearly load test?
Is the portable instrument for measuring oxygen and flammable vapor concentrations in good order and calibrated?
Has the emergency generator been tested, including automatic starting and quick-closing FO valve operation?
Have the main and emergency fire pumps been tested for operation and sufficient delivery pressure?
items.details: Required pressure: 0.27 N/mm² (≥6000 GT), 0.25 N/mm² (<6000 GT).

items.text: Has the steering gear system been tested within 12 hours before departure (all remote controls, alarms, rudder indicators, etc.)?
Is the emergency steering gear drill conducted every 3 months?
Are abandon ship drills and fire drills conducted monthly and within 24 hours of departure if more than 25% of the crew is new?
Is the enclosed space entry and rescue drill conducted every 2 months?
Are weekly inspections of all survival craft, rescue boats and launching appliances performed and recorded?
items.details: Includes running lifeboat engines for 3 mins.

items.text: Are monthly inspections of all life-saving appliances and lifeboat equipment performed using a checklist and recorded?
Is the Magnetic Compass readable, bubble-free, and has a valid deviation curve (updated annually)?
Is the Gyro Compass and its repeaters working correctly with no excessive course difference?
Is the Radar/ARPA/ATA working satisfactorily?
Is the Echo Sounder working satisfactorily?
Is the Speed and Distance Log working satisfactorily?
Is the ECDIS working with the latest official charts (ENC) and software?
Is the AIS working and has its annual test been carried out and recorded?
Is the VDR/S-VDR working and has its annual test been carried out and recorded?
Is the BNWAS working satisfactorily?
Are all navigation lights (masthead, side, stern, anchor) and shapes in good working order?
Is the lifeboat/rescueboat hull, rudder, and all internal fittings in good condition (no rust, damage)?
Does the lifeboat engine start easily and run correctly? Is the inventory (provisions, pyrotechnics) complete and within expiry dates?
Have the launching appliance and on-load release gear had their annual and 5-yearly examinations by an approved service firm?
items.details: Falls to be renewed at intervals not exceeding 5 years.

items.text: Are inflatable liferafts serviced at intervals not exceeding 12 months? Is the hydrostatic release unit within its expiry date?
Are distress flares (12 parachute rockets) available and within their expiry date?
Are lifebuoys correctly stowed, marked, and equipped with lights/smoke signals as required? Are lights and smoke signals within expiry dates?
Is there a lifejacket for every person on board, plus additional for watchkeepers? Are they fitted with a light and whistle?
Are immersion suits provided for every person on board and in good condition?
Are two-way VHF radiotelephone apparatus and radar transponders (SARTs) available and their batteries within expiry dates?
Are line-throwing appliances complete with 4 rockets and are the rockets within their expiry date?
Is the fire integrity of 'A' and 'B' class divisions maintained? Are all penetrations properly sealed?
Do all fire doors, especially self-closing doors, operate satisfactorily and are they free from hold-back devices?
Are fire dampers for engine room, accommodation, and cargo holds operating satisfactorily?
Are the main and emergency fire pumps and their prime movers in good condition and operating correctly?
Is the fire main piping free from leakages, heavy wastage, and temporary repairs (soft patches)?
Are all fire hoses and nozzles in good condition and correctly stowed?
Are portable fire extinguishers correctly located, in good condition, and serviced within required intervals?
Is the fixed fire extinguishing arrangement (CO2, Foam, etc.) in E/R and cargo spaces in good order? Have CO2 cylinders been weighed/checked?
items.details: Is the release alarm tested and working?

items.text: Do the remote shut-off valves for fuel oil tanks operate correctly?
Do the emergency stops for fans and fuel oil pumps operate correctly?
Are all fireman's outfits (min. 2 sets) complete, in good condition, and are breathing apparatus cylinders charged and serviced?
items.details: Are 200% spare air cylinders available or 100% + compressor?

items.text: Are Emergency Escape Breathing Devices (EEBDs) correctly stowed, with air pressure in the acceptable range and within their shelf life?
Is the International Shore Connection available with standard flange, bolts, nuts, and gasket?
Do all radio installations (VHF, MF/HF, INMARSAT) function satisfactorily, including DSC checks?
Does the NAVTEX receiver function correctly?
Has the Satellite EPIRB passed its annual onboard test and 5-yearly shore-based maintenance? Is the battery within its expiry date?
Is the reserve source of energy (batteries) for radio equipment in good condition (checked specific gravity, liquid level, voltage)?
Are antennas and their masts in good condition, without heavy corrosion or damage?
Is the Radio Log Book properly kept with records of daily, weekly, and monthly checks?
Are freeboard marks clearly marked on both sides of the shell plating?
Are doors of all access openings in superstructure bulkheads weathertight, with gaskets and clamping devices in good order?
Are cargo hatches and their coamings in good condition (no heavy wastage or holes) and weathertight?
items.details: Check gaskets, clamping devices, cleats, battens, wedges, and tarpaulins.

items.text: Are machinery space openings, manholes, and flush scuttles weathertight and in good condition?
Are ventilators and their closing arrangements weathertight and in good condition?
Are air pipes, their coamings, and heads in good condition, with floats and wire gauzes intact?
Are scuppers, inlets, and discharges, including their non-return valves, in good order?
Are bulwarks, guard rails, and lifelines in good condition without heavy corrosion or damage?
Is the hull plating (main deck, forecastle, poop) in good order with no heavy wastage, corrosion or cracks?
Are all piping and electrical conduits on deck in good condition?
Are internal structures of cargo holds, ballast tanks, and fuel oil tanks in good condition (no heavy corrosion, wastage, holes)?
Does the Main Engine operate satisfactorily, with all safety/alarm devices and remote controls functioning properly?
Are high-pressure fuel oil pipes jacketed and is the leak alarm in good order?
Do Generator Engines operate satisfactorily with all safety/alarm devices functioning?
Do Boilers operate satisfactorily with safety devices, pressure gauges, and water level gauges in good order?
Is all essential machinery (pumps, etc.) operating correctly with no leakages?
Is all piping free from heavy corrosion, leaks, and temporary repairs (soft patches, cement boxes)?
Are bilge pumps and piping, including the emergency bilge suction, in good order and operating correctly?
Is the Engine Room clean and free from rubbish or waste oil?
Are guards and fencing for moving machinery parts in place and in good condition?
Is insulation for all hot surfaces (above 220°C) and oil spray shields on flanges in good condition?
Are all lights and protective covers in the E/R, accommodation, and other spaces in good order?
Are anti-explosion lights in dangerous spaces (pump room, battery room, paint locker) intact and properly sealed?
Are insulating mats provided around the Main and Emergency Switchboards?
Are emergency batteries in good order (checked specific gravity, liquid level, voltage) and are maintenance records updated?
Does the Emergency Generator operate satisfactorily, including its primary and secondary starting arrangements?
Are anchors, chain cables, and the windlass (including brakes) in good condition?
Is the mooring system (winches, brakes, ropes) in good condition and sufficient for use?
Are Emergency Towing Arrangements (ETA), if required, in good condition?
items.details: For tankers, gas, chemical carriers of not less than 20,000 DWT.

items.text: Does the Oily Water Separator (OWS) operate satisfactorily with no visible oil in the discharged water?
items.details: Check for corrosion on casing and piping.

items.text: Is the 15 PPM alarm and its automatic stopping device functioning properly?
Is the Oil Discharge Monitoring system (ODM) operating correctly?
Is garbage managed correctly according to the Garbage Management Plan, and is the Garbage Record Book maintained?
Does the Sewage Treatment Plant or holding tank system operate satisfactorily?
Are engine parameters being recorded as per the NOx Technical File? Is the fuel oil change-over procedure for SOx Emission Control Areas being followed and recorded?
Does the incinerator, if installed, operate correctly with all safety features intact?
Are masts, booms, jibs and all loose gear (blocks, hooks, shackles, wire ropes) in good condition with no serious wear or damage?
items.details: Check for distinguishing numbers and valid test certificates.

items.text: Have the annual thorough survey and 5-yearly load test of cargo gear been completed and the booklet endorsed?
Are toilets, showers, and laundry facilities clean, in good condition, and with hot water available?
Is the galley clean, with range hoods and ventilation free of oil? Is medical equipment and medicine on board and within validity dates?
Are mess rooms, recreation rooms, and crew cabins clean and free of rubbish?
Are provisions of good quality and quantity, and are cold rooms clean and at the correct temperature?
